utterance: RA: I am the chief scientist of the energy program at Lawrence Livermore National Lab, which is one of the US big federal labs and uh the special part about my role is that we have a big program in negative emissions, trying to understand what they are and to do technology development. utterance: MS: Hi, I'm Marcel. I'm an assistant professor at the University of Wisconsin, Madison in chemistry and chemical engineering, primarily chemical engineering. Um, my background is in electrocatalysis, more on the fundamental side. And what I'm passionate about is to try to find ways to use the principles that make electrocatalysis work to open new pathways for running industrial transformations using renewable electricity instead of heat and pressure as we are doing it nowadays. So say enabling completely sustainable um, uh, chemical industry.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: Marcel explains his background in electrocatalysis and his passion for applying its principles to develop sustainable industrial transformations using renewable electricity.

utterance: GG: Yes, we are. Hi, Roger. Hi, everybody. It's a pleasure to be here. Thanks for having me. Um, my name is Greeshma Gadikota. Uh, affiliation is with chemical and civil and environmental engineering departments at Cornell, also affiliated with chemical and biological engineering. Trained as a chemical engineer, but look at processes that are both related to above ground uh, processes and pathways as well as in subsurface environments. Uh, I'm particularly interested in, um, the next generation of energy and resource conversion pathways and systems. I think there is a lot of innovation that needs to be, uh, harnessed and developed all the way from the molecular scale to implementation, as well as, uh, innovation on the social, on the social side of things in order to make sure that there is acceptance. utterance: EM: Hi, I'm Ellen Matson. I'm an assistant professor at the University of Rochester. Um, my research, I'm a synthetic inorganic chemist and my research group focuses on modeling interfacial reactivity at metal oxide surfaces, um, for applications in small molecule activation. So I'm very interested in taking carbon dioxide or other chemical pollutants and converting them into things that have value.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: Ellen defines her research area as "synthetic inorganic chemistry" and explains her group's focus on "modeling interfacial reactivity at metal oxide surfaces for small molecule activation."

utterance: RS: Hi, I'm Rafael Santos. I'm an assistant professor in environmental engineering at the University of Guelph in Canada. And by background, I'm actually a chemical engineer. So what I've been trying to do is convert some of my chemical engineering knowledge into environmental and also agricultural, um, uh, problems. And that's why I focus on soil mineral amendments as the negative technology that I work with. So spreading minerals on soils and trying to sequester CO2 directly from the atmosphere. And I actually started my work with CO2 sequestration dealing with industrial, uh, processes. So, so I actually have a good idea about how it looks over there and why maybe negative emissions technology might help do what they currently are not able to do.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: Rafael explains his area of expertise, focusing on soil mineral amendments as the negative technology he works with, which involves spreading minerals on soils to sequester CO2 directly from the atmosphere.

utterance: DK: Thanks, Roger. Hi, everyone. My name is David Kowek. I'm the science director for Ocean Visions. Ocean Visions is a small non-profit that's trying to basically seed an ecosystem of ocean solutions. So better connecting research universities and institutions with civil society partners. And a big part of our, um, initial work program is centered around ocean-based carbon dioxide removal. So I co-lead a project that's focused on developing technology road maps for ocean-based carbon dioxide removal, which means that, you know, I'm constantly sort of sitting at the interface of fundamental science and then the needs of sort of all of the, all of the post-scientific needs, the needs of engineers, the needs of entrepreneurs, investors, philanthropists, etc. So I'm really excited to join all of you in this conversation.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: David explains what Ocean Visions is, describing it as "a small non-profit that's trying to basically seed an ecosystem of ocean solutions."

utterance: RA: Thank you, David. Julia.

utterance: JB: Hello. Um, I'm, uh, I started out as a material scientist. Uh, and that actually we can do that whilst developing, uh, a low carbon economy which will provide, um, jobs and economic growth, um, for the UK. So, uh, that's, uh, it's been an interesting, uh, an interesting journey from, uh, from science to, uh, to policy and persuasion.

utterance: RG: Hi, I'm Robert Gilliard from the University of Virginia. Um, I'm a synthetic inorganic chemist, but I specialize in an area of the periodic table that most people know very little about. Uh, main group elements. I've studied the S and P block. We've more recently been developing methods to prepare low valent and also cationic compounds that interact with small molecules such as CO2. So we're trying to understand how, uh, earth abundant elements play a role in CO2 reduction.

utterance: SL: Hi, everyone. Nice to meet you all. Um, I'm Simona Liguori, assistant professor at Clarkson University in the chemical and biomolecular engineering department and a chemical engineer as a background. I mean, in the last 10, 12 years, I work in the energy environmental science and space and above all in thermochemical process and thermochemical transformation. I mean, my work is not directly related to carbon reduction from the atmosphere, so on negative emission technology, but my work is more related to make carbon neutral energy to see and to supply energy to this, you know, negative emission technology because as Dr. Brown showed us, you know, we can have life cycle assessment that we can remove from air two gigatons, you know, of CO2. But at the end, you know, maybe we are going considering the net CO2, we are going just remove 200 megatons, right? So my aim is just to give the energy because if we can think about negative emission from cradle to gate, all that technology needs energy. And I'm here to say, hey, I can make carbon neutral energy in order to, you know, to supply this technology and in order to get the 4% right there. Nice to meet you all.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: Simona explains her background and research focus on thermochemical processes and transformations for carbon-neutral energy production to support negative emission technologies.
